22: ; WARNING: SIP operation behind a NAT is tricky and you really need
23: ; to read and understand well the following section.
25: ; When Asterisk is behind a NAT device, the "local" address (and port) that
26: ; a socket is bound to has different values when seen from the inside or
27: ; from the outside of the NATted network. Unfortunately this address must
28: ; be communicated to the outside (e.g. in SIP and SDP messages), and in
29: ; order to determine the correct value Asterisk needs to know:
31: ; + whether it is talking to someone "inside" or "outside" of the NATted network.
32: ;   This is configured by assigning the "localnet" parameter with a list
33: ;   of network addresses that are considered "inside" of the NATted network.
34: ;   IF LOCALNET IS NOT SET, THE EXTERNAL ADDRESS WILL NOT BE SET CORRECTLY.
35: ;   Multiple entries are allowed, e.g. a reasonable set is the following:
39: ;      localnet=172.16.0.0/12           ; Another RFC1918 with CIDR notation
40: ;      localnet=169.254.0.0/255.255.0.0 ; Zero conf local network
42: ; + the "externally visible" address and port number to be used when talking
43: ;   to a host outside the NAT. This information is derived by one of the
44: ;   following (mutually exclusive) config file parameters:
46: ;   a. "externaddr = hostname[:port]" specifies a static address[:port] to
47: ;      be used in SIP and SDP messages.
48: ;      The hostname is looked up only once, when [re]loading sip.conf .
49: ;      If a port number is not present, use the port specified in the "udpbindaddr"
50: ;      (which is not guaranteed to work correctly, because a NAT box might remap the
51: ;      port number as well as the address).
52: ;      This approach can be useful if you have a NAT device where you can
55: ;        externaddr = 12.34.56.78          ; use this address.
56: ;        externaddr = 12.34.56.78:9900     ; use this address and port.
57: ;        externaddr = mynat.my.org:12600   ; Public address of my nat box.
58: ;        externtcpport = 9900   ; The externally mapped tcp port, when Asterisk is behind a static NAT or PAT.
59: ;                               ; externtcpport will default to the externaddr or externhost port if either one is set.
60: ;        externtlsport = 12600  ; The externally mapped tls port, when Asterisk is behind a static NAT or PAT.

0: ;                               ; externtcpport will default to the externaddr or externhost port if either one is set.
1: ;        externtlsport = 12600  ; The externally mapped tls port, when Asterisk is behind a static NAT or PAT.
2: ;                               ; externtlsport port will default to the RFC designated port of 5061.
4: ;   b. "externhost = hostname[:port]" is similar to "externaddr" except
5: ;      that the hostname is looked up every "externrefresh" seconds
6: ;      (default 10s). This can be useful when your NAT device lets you choose
7: ;      the port mapping, but the IP address is dynamic.
8: ;      Beware, you might suffer from service disruption when the name server
9: ;      resolution fails. Examples:
11: ;        externhost=foo.dyndns.net       ; refreshed periodically
12: ;        externrefresh=180               ; change the refresh interval
14: ;   Note that at the moment all these mechanism work only for the SIP socket.
15: ;   The IP address discovered with externaddr/externhost is reused for
16: ;   media sessions as well, but t
;   media sessions as well, but the port numbers are not remapped so you
17: ;   may still experience problems.
19: ; NOTE 1: in some cases, NAT boxes will use different port numbers in
20: ; the internal<->external mapping. In these cases, the "externaddr" and
21: ; "externhost" might not help you configure addresses properly.
23: ; NOTE 2: when using "externaddr" or "externhost", the address part is
24: ; also used as the external address for media sessions. Thus, the port
25: ; information in the SDP may be wrong!
27: ; In addition to the above, Asterisk has an additional "nat" parameter to
28: ; address NAT-related issues in incoming SIP or media sessions.
29: ; In particular, depending on the 'nat= ' settings described below, Asterisk
30: ; may override the address/port information specified in the SIP/SDP messages,
31: ; and use the information (sender address) supplied by the network stack instead.
32: ; However, this is only useful if the external traffic can reach us.
33: ; The following settings are allowed (both globally and in individual sections):
35: ;        nat = no                ; Use rport if the remote side says to use it.
36: ;        nat = force_rport       ; Force rport to always be on. (default)
37: ;        nat = yes               ; Force rport to always be on and perform comedia RTP handling.
38: ;        nat = comedia           ; Use rport if the remote side says to use it and perform comedia RTP handling.
40: ; 'comedia RTP handling' refers to the technique of sending RTP to the port that the
41: ; the other endpoint's RTP arrived from, and means 'connection-oriented media'. This is
42: ; only partially related to RFC 4145 which was referred to as COMEDIA while it was in
43: ; draft form. This method is used to accomodate endpoints that may be located behind
44: ; NAT devices, and as such the port number they tell Asterisk to send RTP packets to
45: ; for their media streams is not actual port number that will be used on the nearer
46: ; side of the NAT.

52: ; GENERAL SECTION. Specifically, if nat=force_rport in one section and nat=no in the
53: ; other, then valid peers with settings differing from those in the general section will

54: ; SIP entities have a 'type' which determines their roles within Asterisk.
55: ; * For entities with 'type=peer':
56: ;   Peers handle both inbound and outbound calls and are matched by ip/port, so for
57: ;   The case of incoming calls from the peer, the IP address must match in order for
58: ;   The invitation to work. This means calls made from either direction won't work if
59: ;   The peer is unregistered while host=dynamic or if the host is otherise not set to
60: ;   the correct IP of the sender.

0: ;   The peer is unregistered while host=dynamic or if the host is otherise not set to
1: ;   the correct IP of the sender.
2: ; * For entities with 'type=user':
3: ;   Asterisk users handle inbound calls only (meaning they call Asterisk, Asterisk can't
4: ;   call them) and are matched by their authorization information (authname and secret).
5: ;   Asterisk doesn't rely on their IP and will accept calls regardless of the host setting
6: ;   as long as the incoming SIP invite authorizes successfully.
7: ; * For entities with 'type=friend':
8: ;   Asterisk will create the entity as both a friend and a peer. Asterisk will accept
9: ;   calls from friends like it would for users, requiring only that the authorization
10: ;   matches rather than the IP address. Since it is also a peer, a friend entity can
11: ;   be called as long as its IP is known to Asterisk. In the case of host=dynamic,
12: ;   this means it is necessary for the entity to register before Asterisk can call it.
